facts.text: Criminal appeal No. 189 of 1970 filed in Supreme Court.

anchor.surface_text: CRIMINAL APPELLATE JURISDICTION. Criminal appeal No. 189 of 1970.

facts.text: Appeal from Judgment and Order dated 19th February 1970 of Calcutta High Court in Govt. Appeal No. 7 of 1964.

anchor.surface_text: From the Judgment and Order dated the 19th February, 1970 of the Calcutta High Court in Govt. Appeal No. 7 of 1964.

facts.text: Certificate of fitness for appeal to Supreme Court granted by Calcutta High Court under Article 134(1)(c) of Constitution.

anchor.surface_text: This is an appeal on a certificate of fitness of the case for appeal to this Court granted by the Calcutta High Court under Article 134  1   c  of the Constitution of India.

holdings.text: The ingredients of the offence specified as item 2 of the schedule do not differ in any respect from those required by Section 409 I.P.C. for the conviction of a public servant.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Schedule entry limits s409 offences to those committed by public servants in their capacity; ingredients identical to s409 IPC.

holdings.text: The respondent was acting in his capacity as a public servant when he received the monies from policy holders which he misappropriated.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Ostensible or apparent scope of authority and nexus with official capacity determine 'capacity as public servant', not technical internal duty limits.

holdings.text: Acquisition of dominion or control over property must be in the capacity of a public servant for offence under section 409 I.P.C.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Criminal breach of trust involves two parts: creation of obligation via dominion in PS capacity, then dishonest misappropriation.

holdings.text: Ordinarily, it is the ostensible or apparent scope of a public servant's authority, and the use made of his actual official capacity, which determines whether there is a sufficient nexus for section 409 IPC.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Focus on ostensible authority and nexus rather than strict departmental rules to prevent abuse by public servants.

holdings.text: Entrustment under section 409 IPC arises from what the person handing over property believes due to the public servant's exercise of official authority.

anchor.surface_text: The entrustment results from what the person handing over money or property is made to think, understand, and believe about the purpose for which he hands over money or property to a public servant. If this takes place because of an due to the exercise of the official authority

holdings.reasoning_summary: Wide sense of 'entrusted'; includes fraudulent inducement using official capacity.

holdings.text: The respondent is guilty of an offence punishable under section 409 I.P.C. which could be tried by the Special Court.

anchor.surface_text: We, therefore, hold that the respondent is guilty of an offence punishable under section 409 I.P.C. which could be tried by the Special Court.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Facts show misappropriation with sufficient nexus to official capacity; Special Court had jurisdiction under schedule item 2.

holdings.text: The respondent is convicted under section 409 I.P.C. and sentenced to one year's rigorous imprisonment and fine.

anchor.surface_text: Accordingly, we allow this appeal and set aside the orders of the Special Court and the High Court. We convict the respondent under section 409 I.P.C. and we sentence him to one years rigorous imprisonment and to pay a fine of Rs.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Appeal allowed; conviction with reduced sentence considering lapse of time and other mitigating factors.

precedents.citation: State of U.P. Ors. Vs. Babu Ram Upadhya

anchor.surface_text: A case cited before us, to support the contention that acquisition of dominion or possession and control over property by an accused would even if wrongful, be an entrustment or create an obligation the violation of which, by misappropriation, would be punishable under Section 409 I.P.C. if the accused used his official capacity to obtain the property, was State of U.P. Ors. Vs. Babu Ram Upadhya.

precedents.case_name: State of UP & Ors v Babu Ram Upadhya
precedents.cited_proposition: acquisition of dominion or possession and control over property by an accused would even if wrongful, be an entrustment or create an obligation the violation of which, by misappropriation, would be punishable under Section 409 I.P.C. if the accused used his official capacity to obtain the property

precedents.citation: S. N. Puri Vs. State of Rajasthan

anchor.surface_text: Again, in S. N. Puri Vs. State of Rajasthan, this Court, after referring to decisions of different High Courts on the subject, held, that the expression entrusted is used in Section 409 I.P.C. in a wide sense and include all cases in which property is voluntarily handed over for a specific purpose and is dishonestly disposed of contrary to the terms on which possession has been handed over.

precedents.case_name: S N Puri v State of Rajasthan
precedents.cited_proposition: the expression entrusted is used in Section 409 I.P.C. in a wide sense and include all cases in which property is voluntarily handed over for a specific purpose and is dishonestly disposed of contrary to the terms on which possession has been handed over
precedents.cited_holding: the expression entrusted is used in Section 409 I.P.C. in a wide sense and include all cases in which property is voluntarily handed over for a specific purpose and is dishonestly disposed of contrary to the terms on which possession has been handed over
